Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: The Impact of Genetic Health on Parasite Prevalence, Diversity, and Burden in Wild Ring-Tailed Lemurs, Lemur catta

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In vertebrates, genetic diversity influences many elements of an individual's fitness, such as health, survival, and reproduction. 'Inbred' individuals with less genetic diversity have greater parasite loads, reduced survivorship, and produce fewer surviving offspring than do more genetically diverse, or 'outbred" individuals - a phenomenon called inbreeding depression. Beyond these individual costs, inbreeding depression also has negative consequences on populations and species; therefore, understanding how genetic diversity impacts fitness has significant implications for conserving endangered species. Primates are especially vulnerable to inbreeding depression because of their long lifespans and low reproduction rates, yet thus far, no study has investigated how the loss of genetic diversity affects the health, survival, and reproduction of a wild primate population.

The challenge remains to identify the specific genes that can serve as estimates of 'genetic quality' because they influence variation in individual health, survival, and reproduction. One protein-coding region likely to contribute to individual differences is the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC). This family of genes controls the immune system's ability to recognize bacteria, viruses, and parasites, and thus, plays an essential role in the survival of an individual and their offspring.

To examine how MHC impacts fitness in a threatened primate, the ring-tailed lemur (Lemur catta), doctoral student Kathleen Grogan (Duke University), under the supervision of Dr. Christine Drea, will compare MHC diversity against survival, reproductive success, and health across an environmental stressor in a wild population at Beza Mahafaly Special Reserve, Madagascar. Survival and reproductive success, measured using long-term census data, and health, measured as parasite prevalence, diversity, and burden in fecal samples collected (a) under 'typical' environmental conditions and (b) following a severe drought, will be compared against MHC diversity. By examining the relationship between genetic diversity and fitness in wild ring-tailed lemurs, this research tests how individual differences in MHC diversity influence that individual's health, survival, and reproduction. This award will support the training of a graduate student. Additionally, the genetic information will inform conservation efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genetic diversity is required for populations to adapt to environmental change and its loss can be especially detrimental to fragmented populations. At the individual level, loss of genetic diversity is linked to decreased immune function, survival, and reproductive success. Dr. Grogan’s NSF DDIG proposal was part of a larger PhD project to (1) characterize genetic diversity at genes of the Major Histocompatibility complex (MHC) within captive and wild ring-tailed lemurs (Lemur catta). To accomplish this project, Dr. Grogan and her collaborators took advantage of new technologies in next generation sequencing by developing a new protocol for genotyping extremely variable genes (e.g. MHC genes) in non-model species, like the ring-tailed lemur. Dr. Grogan then (2) evaluated how genetic diversity at the most variable MHC gene, MHC-DRB, influences the ability of ring-tailed lemurs to survive and reproduce across different environmental conditions.

At the interface of genetic make-up and survival, the MHC is a large family of genes that controls the immune system’s ability to identify invading bacteria, viruses, and parasites. MHC genes code for the proteins that recognize the difference between ‘self’ proteins (i.e., those proteins made by the body) and ‘non-self’ proteins (i.e., those proteins made by invading pathogens). Thus, the MHC is responsible for activating the immune system in the presence of ‘non-self’ proteins, and each MHC molecule recognizes a particular subset of pathogens. Therefore, an individual that is genetically diverse at its MHC genes is capable of mounting an immune defense against a greater variety of infections than is an individual that has little MHC genetic diversity. Because of its function, the MHC plays an essential role in an individual’s fitness, or its survival and reproductive success, as well as that of its offspring. To explore the relationship between MHC and fitness, Dr. Grogan compared MHC diversity to long term health, survival, and reproduction records for captive ring-tailed lemurs from the Duke Lemur Center as well as wild ring-tailed lemurs from Beza Mahafaly Special Reserve, Madagascar. Using these two populations allowed her to evaluate the effect of environmental condition on the relationship between MHC diversity and fitness. The captive population lives under ‘constant’ environmental conditions, while the wild population experienced extremely variable environmental conditions, including three environmental stressors: a famine in 2005 caused by a cyclone, a drought in 2006, and a second drought in 2010.

Dr. Grogan found that in ‘constant’ environmental conditions, e.g. in captivity, individuals with fewer MHC alleles are significantly more likely to die at a younger age than individuals with greater MHC-DRB diversity. In contrast, when environmental conditions vary, e.g. in the wild, the influence of MHC diversity on survival may be altered by extreme stressors like droughts. During ‘non-stressor’ years, the average MHC diversity of surviving individuals is greater than the average MHC diversity of individuals that perished. This difference disappears, however, during environmental stressors as there is no difference in the average MHC diversity of surviving individuals compared to the average MHC diversity of individuals that perished during a stressor. The MHC also influences reproductive success in the wild but only during non-stressor years: Female lemurs with certain MHC alleles have increased weaning success. Conversely, females with different MHC alleles suffer an increased risk of infant death prior to weaning or are more likely to fail to give birth.
